II. Purpose of Addendum
The facility has requested and received a licensing change. They were licensed as
a Therapeutic Child Caring Institution and are now licensed as a Child Caring
Institution. This change allows the facility to use approved Behavior management
techniques to ensure the safety of youth in their program, which was not allowed
under the old license. The facility will also provide shelter care services through a
shelter care contract.

IV. Description of Findings and Conclusions
The facility provided a new program description which includes the changes in the
treatment program.
Gail’s House will provide Shelter Foster Care Services for four females primarily
aged 10-15 years old (through exception the ages may be 5-17 and the number
may increase to 6 females) who are unable to be placed in a family foster home
and need temporary placement due to several issues. The issues include:
2

a. Child presents at removal with significant behavioral challenges or
other complex factors requiring a comprehensive assessment to
either reunify or select an out-of-home placement.
b. Child is currently on a waiting list for a long-term residential program.
c. Child is in the process of stepping down from hospitalization.
d. Child has a documented severe score on the Mental Health and
Well-Being item on the Child Assessment of Needs and Strengths
within the past 90 days and has repeated placement instability and a
more thorough assessment is needed to either reunify or make a
stable next placement.
Gail’s House will accept crisis placement 24-hours a day, 7 days a week and 365
days a year. The facility will not reject any youth referred by any MDHHS County
Office, PAFC agency, RPU or 24-Hour Unit. The program will be licensed to
provide care for six residents at a time in a safe residential environment.
At the time of placement, the facility will provide a safe residential environment
with a focus on evaluation for services. This will involve gathering information in
order to facilitate service planning and placement stability.
Each child will receive a bio-psychosocial assessment upon entry to the shelter
including family members if possible. They will be administrated the Child
Assessment of Needs and Strengths (CANS) along with the Casey life skills
assessment. These screening tools will be used to assess the level of supervision
the child will need to ensure a safe and nurturing environment is provided. The
facility will provide one-on-one supervision of youth if it is determined that this level
is required. This will be coordinated with the referring agency. At the time of entry
to the shelter, the initial planning for discharge / transition will begin. The expected
length of stay is 30-days, as stated in the contract, but exceptions will be made.
Exceptions can occur if the referring agency is having difficulty finding a treatment
program placement for the youth.
The facility will provide the following services for youth in their care:
 Positive Behavioral Supports structured lessons (PBS)
 TARGET focused activity (Trauma Affect Regulation: Guide to Education
and Therapy)
 Clinical Case Management and Crisis Counseling (Family therapy also
offered)
 Educational activities aimed at keeping the student current with each home
school district or arrange for attendance at the local school
 Structured recreational physical activities
 Structured recreational activities such as art projects, team building, and
games
3

 Support of family and sibling visits
 Support of family participation in Family Team Meetings (FTM)
 Coordination of Medical/Dental care as needed
 Discharge planning
Because the facility is a 6-bed facility, the staffing ratio is designed to be 1:4 or 2:6
during awake hours and 1:6 during sleeping hours. If it is determined that a
resident requires a higher level of supervision, the facility will provide if necessary
1:1 ratio for those residents. This increased level of supervision will be coordinated
with the referring worker and have an ongoing evaluation of the need. Structure is
provided for the children while in the program which includes monitoring and
supervision through direct contact, eyes on and verbal communication.
Gail’s House treatment team consists of highly trained (licensed where required)
professionals (Program Director, Program Manager, Direct Care Staff Supervisor,
Clinical Staff, Specialists, Support Staff, and Direct Care Staff) with skills in
treatment plan development, de-escalation techniques, crisis intervention, and
skills development for the residents. Each of the treatment staff are required to
attend significant training on different interventions and methods of positive
interventions. The facility will have a Licensed Therapist available on site and/or
on call for crisis counseling. The facility also has an active camera system that will
provide additional support for residents and staff.
Upon admission to the shelter, each resident will undergo a complete assessment
by the facility so a 7-calendar day preliminary assessment and plan can be
developed. This involves an assessment which is individualized, strength-based,
trauma informed, family-focused, culturally responsive assessment that informs
and guides service delivery and discharge planning. Assessments are conducted
face-to-face and include an assessment of natural supports and resources.
Assessments and plan will include:
 A comprehensive assessment of the child’s physical/mental health needs
 An assessment of the child’s immediate and specific needs and diagnosis
 The specific services to be provided by the contractor and other resources
to meet the identified needs
 Goals, outcomes and timeframes for achievement
 Placement recommendation
 Barriers to achievement of the recommended placement and plans to
eliminate barriers.
Following admission to the facility, the therapist will work with identified individuals
significant to the resident in the development of the 20-calendar day report. Each
plan will include the following items:
 A psychiatric history, as necessary
4

 A social history
 A mental status examination
 An assessment of trauma history
 Intelligence and projective tests review, if necessary
 A behavioral appraisal
 Family, environmental, cultural, and religious or spiritual preference
 Behaviors that necessitated a more restrictive placement setting for the
child
 Reviewing previous psychotherapeutic and psychiatric assessments and
treatment
 An updated assessment of the child’s specific needs and diagnosis
 Placement recommendations
 Recommended service to meet the child’s identified needs.
The daily focus of the residents will center on several different aspects. These
aspects include the developmental needs of children:
 Physical Activity
 Competence and Achievement
 Self-Definition
 Creative Expression
 Positive Social Interaction
 Structure and Clear Limits
 Meaningful Participation
 Strong Attachment with Positive Adults
Gail’s House utilizes the Positive Behavior Support (PBS) system, which has a
focus of reinforcing a resident’s positive behaviors. This program also involves
engaging the resident in numerous on-site and community activities (depending on
the age and development abilities of the resident). Activities that are identified are
those activities that support the treatment goals and help to build positive skills
within the resident. On-site activities include the “Activity Center”, gym, and
utilizing outdoor space (walking track or basketball court).
Direct Care Staff are trained in the Mandt System® utilizing nonphysical and
physical techniques in a graded and gradual system from least restrictive to most
restrictive. Staff will utilize the least restrictive physical intervention techniques,
including physical restraint, for physical aggression or dangerous behaviors which
places the child and/or others at risk. Staff may not use any physical intervention
techniques except for the Mandt System® while working in Program, regardless of
5

certification. Staff are not allowed to engage in physical intervention if they are not
currently certified in the Mandt System®.
At this time, Gail’s House will receive referrals from MDHHS County Office, PAFC
agency, RPU or 24-Hour Unit.
The facility has made changes in their services provided to residents. These
changes require the facility to use behavior management techniques to provide a
safe environment. Because of this need, the facility was not able to provide the
safety necessary under the Therapeutic Child Caring Institution license.
V. Recommendation
It is recommended that a new license be issued to this Child Caring Institution.
